subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Re: how to transcribe air and ear
msgSnippet: ... That the sound is prolonged to roughly double length.  This is allophonic in most Englishes (the vowel of bed is pronounced longer than that of bet ,
messageBody:
paulhtremblay scripsit:

> (What does ":" mean after a symbol?)

That the sound is prolonged to roughly double length. This is allophonic in
most Englishes (the vowel of "bed" is pronounced longer than that of
"bet", but it doesn't affect anything if you get this wrong), but
in Australian English it is highly significant: the only distinction
between "cup" and "carp" is vowel length.

> (On the other hand, thiking aloud, Germany has dialects that are so
> different that a German from the North has trouble understanding a
> speaker from some regions of the South, yet Germany has one very
> simle, effective phonemic alphabet.)

That's because German orthography is based on an artificial version
of German that is nobody's native language: roughly speaking it has
an older form of Southern grammar with very few Northern influences,
but the orthography is pretty much Northern, or perhaps better,
a Northerner's idea of how to pronounce a moderately Southern variety.

--
John Cowan http://ccil.org/~cowan cowan@...
SAXParserFactory [is] a hideous, evil monstrosity of a class that should
be hung, shot, beheaded, drawn and quartered, burned at the stake,
buried in unconsecrated ground, dug up, cremated, and the ashes tossed
in the Tiber while the complete cast of Wicked sings "Ding dong, the
witch is dead." --Elliotte Rusty Harold on xml-dev
